--- title: "Multivariate Analysis I: PCA in R (tidyverse workflow)" author: "Dr. Adrian Correndo" date: "2026-02-04" categories: [multivariate analysis, PCA, tidyverse, ggplot2, reproducible workflow] format: html: toc: true toc-location: left toc-depth: 4 number-sections: true table-class: "table table-striped table-hover" editor: source smooth-scroll: true bibliography: ../../references.bib link-citations: TRUE --- **Description**
This class introduces **Principal Component Analysis (PCA)** as a practical tool for exploring multivariate agronomic datasets. We will use a **tidyverse-style workflow**: tidy data → preprocessing → PCA → tidy outputs → interpretation + visualization (scree plots, score plots, biplots). **Learning goals**
- Understand what PCA does (and what it does *not* do). - Decide when PCA is appropriate (and when it is not). - Run PCA in R using `prcomp()` and **tidy** the results with `broom`. - Build a PCA biplot in `ggplot2` (scores + loadings). - Avoid common pitfalls: scaling, missing values, outliers, and the “PCA with only 2 variables” trap. - (Optional) Use `factoextra` and `ggfortify` for quick PCA visualization. --- # Required packages for today ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} library(pacman) p_load( dplyr, tidyr, stringr, lubridate, janitor, ggplot2, ggrepel, skimr, broom, tibble, purrr, scales ) ``` ::: ::: callout-note ## Optional packages (nice shortcuts) If you want quick “one-liner” PCA plots, install/use these: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} p_load(factoextra, ggfortify) # optional (sometimes used with factoextra): # p_load(FactoMineR) ``` ::: We keep them optional so your document still renders if those packages are not installed. ::: ::: callout-tip ## Reproducibility tip If you simulate data (as we do below), always set a seed. ::: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} set.seed(123) ``` ::: --- # PCA in one paragraph (intuition) PCA finds **new axes** (principal components) that are linear combinations of your original variables. - **PC1** captures the greatest possible variance. - **PC2** captures the greatest remaining variance, **orthogonal** to PC1. - With *p* variables, PCA produces up to *p* components. --- # When PCA makes sense Use PCA when you have: - Several **numeric** variables (often ≥ 4–5) measured on the same observations - Possible **correlation structure** among variables - A goal of **exploration**, dimensionality reduction, or summarizing multivariate patterns Avoid PCA (or be very cautious) when: - You only have **2 variables** (a scatterplot often communicates more) - Variables are on very different scales and you don’t scale/center - Many missing values, strong non-linear patterns, or extreme outliers dominate --- # Mini-case study dataset (agronomy style) We’ll build a small dataset that resembles a field trial summary with soil, canopy, and yield/quality variables. ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} trial <- tibble( site = rep(paste0("Site_", 1:4), each = 30), hybrid = sample(paste0("H", 1:6), size = 120, replace = TRUE), yield_mg_ha = rnorm(120, mean = 11.0, sd = 1.2), protein_pct = rnorm(120, mean = 8.5, sd = 0.6), oil_pct = rnorm(120, mean = 4.2, sd = 0.3), ndvi = pmin(pmax(rnorm(120, mean = 0.78, sd = 0.06), 0.4), 0.95), soil_no3_ppm = rgamma(120, shape = 8, rate = 0.25), om_pct = rnorm(120, mean = 3.5, sd = 0.7) ) %>% # add some realistic correlation (just for teaching) mutate( yield_mg_ha = yield_mg_ha + 0.03 * soil_no3_ppm + 2.0 * (ndvi - mean(ndvi)), protein_pct = protein_pct + 0.10 * (om_pct - mean(om_pct)), oil_pct = oil_pct - 0.05 * (protein_pct - mean(protein_pct)) ) trial %>% glimpse() ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` Rows: 120 Columns: 8 $ site "Site_1", "Site_1", "Site_1", "Site_1", "Site_1", "Site_1… $ hybrid "H3", "H6", "H3", "H2", "H2", "H6", "H3", "H5", "H4", "H6… $ yield_mg_ha 12.604488, 11.199810, 12.694071, 11.599757, 12.630814, 13… $ protein_pct 9.340974, 8.315917, 8.847161, 8.274744, 8.136453, 7.90097… $ oil_pct 4.525710, 3.809898, 4.383214, 4.056715, 4.425627, 4.21403… $ ndvi 0.8072862, 0.8195942, 0.7680066, 0.7412932, 0.7899193, 0.… $ soil_no3_ppm 36.674506, 19.268982, 31.915381, 31.813683, 40.849757, 31… $ om_pct 4.084081, 3.298861, 3.761269, 3.782303, 2.770829, 2.29018… ``` ::: ::: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} trial %>% skimr::skim() ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} Table: Data summary | | | |:------------------------|:----------| |Name |Piped data | |Number of rows |120 | |Number of columns |8 | |_______________________ | | |Column type frequency: | | |character |2 | |numeric |6 | |________________________ | | |Group variables |None | **Variable type: character** |skim_variable | n_missing| complete_rate| min| max| empty| n_unique| whitespace| |:-------------|---------:|-------------:|---:|---:|-----:|--------:|----------:| |site | 0| 1| 6| 6| 0| 4| 0| |hybrid | 0| 1| 2| 2| 0| 6| 0| **Variable type: numeric** |skim_variable | n_missing| complete_rate| mean| sd| p0| p25| p50| p75| p100|hist | |:-------------|---------:|-------------:|-----:|-----:|----:|-----:|-----:|-----:|-----:|:-----| |yield_mg_ha | 0| 1| 11.94| 1.26| 8.92| 11.07| 11.79| 12.66| 15.73|▂▇▇▂▁ | |protein_pct | 0| 1| 8.55| 0.58| 7.33| 8.17| 8.49| 8.96| 9.85|▃▇▇▅▃ | |oil_pct | 0| 1| 4.19| 0.31| 3.42| 4.00| 4.21| 4.39| 5.00|▂▅▇▅▁ | |ndvi | 0| 1| 0.79| 0.06| 0.62| 0.75| 0.79| 0.83| 0.93|▁▃▇▆▁ | |soil_no3_ppm | 0| 1| 31.74| 11.04| 5.91| 24.25| 31.14| 39.26| 72.55|▂▇▅▂▁ | |om_pct | 0| 1| 3.55| 0.72| 1.74| 3.19| 3.65| 4.03| 5.38|▂▃▇▅▁ | ::: ::: --- # Step 1: Select numeric variables for PCA PCA requires numeric variables. We typically keep ID columns (site/hybrid) separate so we can label points later. ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} trial_x <- trial %>% select(where(is.numeric)) trial_ids <- trial %>% select(site, hybrid) trial_x %>% glimpse() ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` Rows: 120 Columns: 6 $ yield_mg_ha 12.604488, 11.199810, 12.694071, 11.599757, 12.630814, 13… $ protein_pct 9.340974, 8.315917, 8.847161, 8.274744, 8.136453, 7.90097… $ oil_pct 4.525710, 3.809898, 4.383214, 4.056715, 4.425627, 4.21403… $ ndvi 0.8072862, 0.8195942, 0.7680066, 0.7412932, 0.7899193, 0.… $ soil_no3_ppm 36.674506, 19.268982, 31.915381, 31.813683, 40.849757, 31… $ om_pct 4.084081, 3.298861, 3.761269, 3.782303, 2.770829, 2.29018… ``` ::: ::: ::: callout-note ## Scaling choice: covariance vs correlation PCA - If variables have very different units (ppm vs % vs indices), use **center + scale** (correlation PCA). - If all variables share units and scale is meaningful, you may use only centering. - **center** = subtract mean; **scale** = divide by standard deviation. In this class we use **center + scale**, so 0 is the mean and values are in units of standard deviations. ::: --- # Step 2: Run PCA with `prcomp()` (tidy-friendly) ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} pca_fit <- trial_x %>% prcomp(center = TRUE, scale. = TRUE) ``` ::: --- # Step 3: Tidy the PCA outputs (scores, loadings, variance explained) ## 3.1 Scores (PC coordinates for observations) ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} scores <- broom::augment(pca_fit, data = trial_x) %>% bind_cols(trial_ids) %>% janitor::clean_names() scores %>% select(site, hybrid, starts_with("fitted_pc")) %>% glimpse() ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` Rows: 120 Columns: 8 $ site "Site_1", "Site_1", "Site_1", "Site_1", "Site_1", "Site_1",… $ hybrid "H3", "H6", "H3", "H2", "H2", "H6", "H3", "H5", "H4", "H6",… $ fitted_pc1 -0.16791473, 0.91268899, -0.20891808, -0.08358898, -0.88782… $ fitted_pc2 0.4958326, -0.1486580, 0.1923104, 0.4392422, -1.2628698, -1… $ fitted_pc3 0.20368904, -1.04876029, 0.48619725, 0.57516114, 0.12898922… $ fitted_pc4 1.26160208, -0.28233182, 0.31255832, -0.47831581, -0.565797… $ fitted_pc5 -1.51618531, 1.26469212, -0.75918494, 0.68922955, -0.598664… $ fitted_pc6 -0.043638971, -0.317781176, -0.464303028, 0.026272462, 0.38… ``` ::: ::: ## 3.2 Loadings (how variables contribute to each PC) ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} loadings <- broom::tidy(pca_fit, matrix = "rotation") %>% janitor::clean_names() %>% rename(variable = column) # First 2 dimensions loadings %>% filter(pc %in% c(1,2)) %>% arrange(pc, desc(abs(value))) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` # A tibble: 12 × 3 variable pc value 1 yield_mg_ha 1 -0.659 2 soil_no3_ppm 1 -0.648 3 protein_pct 1 0.335 4 om_pct 1 -0.148 5 oil_pct 1 0.107 6 ndvi 1 0.00921 7 protein_pct 2 0.557 8 om_pct 2 0.516 9 oil_pct 2 -0.504 10 ndvi 2 -0.360 11 soil_no3_ppm 2 0.177 12 yield_mg_ha 2 -0.0942 ``` ::: ::: ## 3.3 Variance explained (scree table) ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} var_explained <- tibble( pc = paste0("PC", seq_along(pca_fit$sdev)), sd = pca_fit$sdev, var = sd^2, prop_var = var / sum(var), cum_prop_var = cumsum(prop_var) ) var_explained ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` # A tibble: 6 × 5 pc sd var prop_var cum_prop_var 1 PC1 1.22 1.48 0.247 0.247 2 PC2 1.15 1.32 0.220 0.468 3 PC3 1.03 1.05 0.175 0.643 4 PC4 0.926 0.857 0.143 0.786 5 PC5 0.830 0.690 0.115 0.901 6 PC6 0.771 0.594 0.0990 1 ``` ::: ::: --- # Visualization 1: Scree plot + cumulative variance ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} var_explained %>% ggplot(aes(x = pc, y = prop_var)) + geom_col(aes(fill = pc)) + # add labels to cols geom_text(aes(label = scales::percent(prop_var, accuracy = 1)), vjust = -0.5, size = 3) + geom_point(aes(y = cum_prop_var, group = 1)) + geom_line(aes(y = cum_prop_var, group = 1)) + # add labels to line/points geom_text(aes(y = cum_prop_var, label = scales::percent(cum_prop_var, accuracy = 1)), vjust = -1, size = 3) + scale_y_continuous(labels = scales::percent_format(accuracy = 1)) + labs( title = "Variance explained by principal components", x = NULL, y = "Proportion of variance (bars) and cumulative (line/points)" ) ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](PCA_factoextra_ggfortify_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-11-1.png){width=672} ::: ::: ::: callout-tip ## Rule of thumb (exploratory) If PC1 + PC2 explains a modest share (e.g., 50–70%), a 2D plot may still be useful, but don’t over-interpret. If PC1 + PC2 explains very little, consider 3D, more PCs, or different methods. ::: --- # Visualization 2: Score plot (PC1 vs PC2) ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} scores %>% ggplot(aes(x = fitted_pc1, y = fitted_pc2, shape = site)) + geom_point(alpha = 0.75, aes(color=site)) + labs( title = "PCA score plot", x = "PC1 score", y = "PC2 score" ) + # add lines at 0 geom_hline(yintercept = 0, linetype = "dashed", color = "gray50") + geom_vline(xintercept = 0, linetype = "dashed", color = "gray50") + theme_classic()+ theme(legend.position = "right") ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](PCA_factoextra_ggfortify_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-12-1.png){width=672} ::: ::: --- # Visualization 3: PCA biplot in ggplot2 (scores + loadings) A biplot overlays: - points = **scores** (observations) - arrows = **loadings** (variables) Because scores and loadings are on different scales, we apply a simple scaling factor so arrows are visible. ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} # Prepare a small loadings table for PC1/PC2 loadings_12 <- loadings %>% filter(pc %in% c(1, 2)) %>% select(variable, pc, value) %>% pivot_wider(names_from = pc, values_from = value) %>% rename(loading_pc1 = `1`, loading_pc2 = `2`) # Scaling factor to make arrows fit the score space arrow_scale <- scores %>% summarise( scale = min( (max(fitted_pc1) - min(fitted_pc1)) / (max(abs(loadings_12$loading_pc1)) * 2), (max(fitted_pc2) - min(fitted_pc2)) / (max(abs(loadings_12$loading_pc2)) * 2) ) ) %>% pull(scale) arrow_scale ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` [1] 5.680948 ``` ::: ::: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} scores %>% ggplot(aes(x = fitted_pc1, y = fitted_pc2)) + geom_point(aes(shape = site, color=site), alpha = 0.75) + geom_segment( data = loadings_12, aes( x = 0, y = 0, xend = loading_pc1 * arrow_scale, yend = loading_pc2 * arrow_scale ), inherit.aes = FALSE, linewidth = 0.7, arrow = arrow(length = unit(0.02, "npc")) ) + ggrepel::geom_text_repel( data = loadings_12, aes( x = loading_pc1 * arrow_scale, y = loading_pc2 * arrow_scale, label = variable ), inherit.aes = FALSE, size = 4 ) + # add lines at 0 geom_hline(yintercept = 0, linetype = "dashed", color = "gray50") + geom_vline(xintercept = 0, linetype = "dashed", color = "gray50") + theme_classic()+ theme(legend.position = "right") ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](PCA_factoextra_ggfortify_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-14-1.png){width=672} ::: ::: --- # Optional visualization shortcuts ## Option A: `factoextra` (quick, publication-style plots) `factoextra` makes it easy to produce consistent PCA plots (scree, individuals, variables, biplots) with many options (ellipses, repel labels, cos2 coloring, contributions). ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} library(factoextra) # Scree plot fviz_eig(pca_fit, addlabels = TRUE) ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](PCA_factoextra_ggfortify_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-15-1.png){width=672} ::: ```{.r .cell-code} # Individuals (scores) fviz_pca_ind( pca_fit, geom.ind = "point", habillage = trial$site, # group by site addEllipses = TRUE, repel = TRUE ) ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](PCA_factoextra_ggfortify_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-15-2.png){width=672} ::: ```{.r .cell-code} # Variables (loadings) fviz_pca_var( pca_fit, col.var = "contrib", # color by contribution repel = TRUE ) ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](PCA_factoextra_ggfortify_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-15-3.png){width=672} ::: ```{.r .cell-code} # Biplot (scores + loadings) fviz_pca_biplot( pca_fit, habillage = trial$site, addEllipses = FALSE, repel = TRUE ) ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](PCA_factoextra_ggfortify_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-15-4.png){width=672} ::: ::: ::: callout-tip ## Good teaching moments with `factoextra` - `col.var = "contrib"` vs `col.var = "cos2"` (importance vs quality of representation) - `addEllipses = TRUE` for group structure - `select.var` / `select.ind` to reduce clutter ::: ## Option B: `ggfortify::autoplot()` (fast biplot with ggplot theme) `ggfortify` gives a clean “one-liner” biplot from a `prcomp` object. ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} library(ggfortify) autoplot( pca_fit, data = trial, colour = "site", # color by site (column in data) shape = "hybrid", loadings = TRUE, loadings.label = TRUE, loadings.label.repel = TRUE ) + labs( title = "PCA biplot via ggfortify", x = "PC1", y = "PC2" )+ # We can add GEOMS as if it were a ggplot # add lines at 0 geom_hline(yintercept = 0, linetype = "dashed", color = "gray50") + geom_vline(xintercept = 0, linetype = "dashed", color = "gray50") + theme_classic() ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](PCA_factoextra_ggfortify_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-16-1.png){width=672} ::: ::: ::: callout-note ## When to prefer each - **Your custom ggplot biplot**: maximum control + teaches the mechanics. - **factoextra**: fastest path to high-quality PCA figures + many diagnostics. - **ggfortify**: quickest “ggplot-friendly” biplot for reports and labs. ::: --- # How to interpret the biplot **Points (scores)** - Points close together have similar multivariate profiles (in the variables you used). - Separation along PC1 suggests differences in the “PC1 gradient.” **Arrows (loadings)** - Arrow length indicates how strongly a variable aligns with the PC space. - The angle between arrows approximates correlation: - small angle → positive correlation - ~180° → negative correlation - ~90° → weak/none **Caution**: Interpretation is only meaningful for variables included, and depends heavily on scaling. --- # The “PCA with only 2 variables” trap (what your student saw) If you run PCA with only **two variables**, you always have two components that span the full 2D space. So **PC1 + PC2 = 100% variance explained** (by definition). That does *not* mean the PCA is “perfect”; it means you didn’t reduce dimension. ## Quick demo ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} two_vars <- trial %>% select(yield_mg_ha, ndvi) pca_2 <- two_vars %>% prcomp(center = TRUE, scale. = TRUE) # Here we see 100% variance explained because there are only 2 variables tibble( pc = paste0("PC", seq_along(pca_2$sdev)), prop_var = (pca_2$sdev^2) / sum(pca_2$sdev^2) ) %>% mutate(prop_var = scales::percent(prop_var, accuracy = 0.1)) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` # A tibble: 2 × 2 pc prop_var 1 PC1 53.1% 2 PC2 46.9% ``` ::: ::: ::: callout-important ## Teaching message With only 2 variables, a **scatter plot** of the standardized variables typically communicates the same information as a PCA biplot, and the “100% variance explained” is expected. ::: --- # Optional: A tidy preprocessing pipeline with `recipes` (tidymodels) If you want a consistent “data recipe” approach, you can use `recipes` for centering/scaling and PCA. ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} library(recipes) rec <- recipe(~ ., data = trial_x) %>% step_normalize(all_predictors()) %>% step_pca(all_predictors(), num_comp = 3) rec_prep <- prep(rec) pca_scores <- bake(rec_prep, new_data = NULL) # scores pca_loadings <- tidy(rec_prep, number = 2) # loadings for step_pca ``` ::: --- # Common pitfalls checklist ::: panel-tabset ## Scaling & units - If you mix variables in different units (ppm, %, index), use `scale. = TRUE`. - Always report whether PCA used covariance or correlation scaling. ## Missing values - `prcomp()` does not accept missing values. - Options: remove rows, impute, or use specialized PCA methods. ## Outliers - PCA is sensitive to outliers. - Inspect distributions and consider robust alternatives if needed. ## Interpretation overload - PCs are **linear combinations**; avoid forcing causal stories. - Use PCA as exploration, then validate with targeted models/experiments. ::: --- # In-class exercises 1. **Scaling sensitivity**: run PCA with `scale. = FALSE`. How do the loadings and variance explained change? 2. **Variable selection**: drop one variable (e.g., `ndvi`). Does your interpretation of PC1 change? 3. **Group structure**: color the score plot by `hybrid`. Do you see separation among hybrids? 4. **Compare plotting tools**: create the biplot using (i) your ggplot biplot, (ii) `factoextra`, and (iii) `ggfortify`. What do you gain/lose? --- # Wrap-up Today you learned a tidy workflow for PCA: - select numeric variables - scale/center appropriately - run PCA (`prcomp`) - tidy outputs (scores + loadings + variance explained) - visualize and interpret cautiously **Next class idea**: clustering (k-means or hierarchical) on PCA scores + validation. ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} sessionInfo() ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` R version 4.4.2 (2024-10-31) Platform: aarch64-apple-darwin20 Running under: macOS Sequoia 15.6.1 Matrix products: default BLAS: /Library/Frameworks/R.framework/Versions/4.4-arm64/Resources/lib/libRblas.0.dylib LAPACK: /Library/Frameworks/R.framework/Versions/4.4-arm64/Resources/lib/libRlapack.dylib; LAPACK version 3.12.0 locale: [1] en_US.UTF-8/en_US.UTF-8/en_US.UTF-8/C/en_US.UTF-8/en_US.UTF-8 time zone: America/Toronto tzcode source: internal attached base packages: [1] stats graphics grDevices utils datasets methods base other attached packages: [1] ggfortify_0.4.19 factoextra_1.0.7 scales_1.4.0 purrr_1.2.0 [5] tibble_3.3.0 broom_1.0.11 skimr_2.2.1 ggrepel_0.9.6 [9] ggplot2_4.0.1 janitor_2.2.1 lubridate_1.9.4 stringr_1.6.0 [13] tidyr_1.3.1 dplyr_1.1.4 pacman_0.5.1 loaded via a namespace (and not attached): [1] utf8_1.2.6 generics_0.1.4 rstatix_0.7.3 stringi_1.8.7 [5] digest_0.6.39 magrittr_2.0.4 evaluate_1.0.5 grid_4.4.2 [9] timechange_0.3.0 RColorBrewer_1.1-3 fastmap_1.2.0 jsonlite_2.0.0 [13] backports_1.5.0 Formula_1.2-5 gridExtra_2.3 abind_1.4-8 [17] cli_3.6.5 rlang_1.1.6 base64enc_0.1-3 withr_3.0.2 [21] repr_1.1.7 yaml_2.3.11 tools_4.4.2 ggsignif_0.6.4 [25] ggpubr_0.6.2 vctrs_0.6.5 R6_2.6.1 lifecycle_1.0.4 [29] snakecase_0.11.1 car_3.1-3 htmlwidgets_1.6.4 pkgconfig_2.0.3 [33] pillar_1.11.1 gtable_0.3.6 glue_1.8.0 Rcpp_1.1.0 [37] xfun_0.54 tidyselect_1.2.1 rstudioapi_0.17.1 knitr_1.50 [41] dichromat_2.0-0.1 farver_2.1.2 htmltools_0.5.9 carData_3.0-5 [45] labeling_0.4.3 rmarkdown_2.30 compiler_4.4.2 S7_0.2.1 ``` ::: :::
